talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 5 September 2005:

item.para: Is he aware of claims by the National Council of Resistance of Iran that the Iranian Government is covertly building and concealing thousands of centrifuge rigs used to enrich uranium for nuclear fuel or weapons.
Has the Government taken any action to try to prevent Iran from acquiring uranium which could ultimately be converted into nuclear weapons.

Does the Government share the Government of the United Statesâ view that Iran has forfeited its right to a full nuclear program by deceiving inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency for years about the extent of Iranâs activities.
Has Iran breached its undertaking to the International Atomic Energy Agency that it would not add to its stock of 164 centrifuges.
Has the Government taken any action following Iranâs decision to resume uranium conversion at a nuclear plant near Isfahan.
Is he able to say whether the nuclear technology for generating electricity can be used to process uranium in order to make nuclear weapons.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

As Australia has not concluded a bilateral safeguards agreement with Iran, Australia does not supply uranium to Iran, not do we consent to retransfer of Australian Obligated Nuclear Material to Iran from any of Australiaâs bilateral agreement partners. Australia supports efforts â including as a member of the Board of Governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) â to ensure that all of Iranâs nuclear activities, materials and facilities are safeguarded by the IAEA.

Australia supports the right of all Parties to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) to benefit from the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, as set out in Article IV of the NPT. However, this right is not unqualified, and is subject to other provisions of the NPT, especially Article III which requires non-nuclear-weapon States Parties to place all nuclear material under IAEA safeguards, and Article II which prohibits such states from seeking to acquire nuclear weapons. Iran cannot comply with the Treaty selectively, invoking rights under some provisions while violating others.

The IAEA has not been able to establish whether there is any substance to media reports that Iran has produced larger numbers of centrifuges. However, IAEA Director-General ElBaradeiâs report to the IAEA Board of Governors of 2 September states that the IAEA is âstill not in a position to conclude that there are no undeclared nuclear materials or activities in Iran.â

Yes. The Australian Government is actively encouraging Iran to suspend its sensitive nuclear activities and return to negotiations with the EU3 (the United Kingdom, France and Germany). In addition to making representations to Iranian diplomatic representatives here in Australia, Australia is strongly supportive of the work of the IAEA and, most recently, backed a 24 September IAEA Board of Governors resolution which found Iran in non-compliance with its safeguards obligations. In a meeting with Iranian Foreign Minister Mottaki in New York in September, I reiterated Australiaâs position, including the importance of the EU3-Iran process and reinforced the benefits that would flow to Iran from an agreement with the EU3.

Nuclear energy as such â the use of reactors to generate electricity â does not present a proliferation risk. Proliferation can be an issue, however, with enrichment and reprocessing, technologies used to produce fissile material for reactor fuel but which could also be used in the production of weapons-grade fissile material. Accordingly, safeguards arrangements, which are designed to detect the diversion of nuclear material or technology from civil to military use, and the application of export controls on the proliferation-sensitive enrichment and reprocessing technologies (e.g. through the Nuclear Suppliers Group â see www.nuclearsuppliersgroup.org) are key elements in the nuclear non-proliferation regime. Further information on the nuclear fuel cycle and safeguards can be found in ASNOâs Annual Reports, at www.asno.dfat.gov.au.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, in writing, on 6 September 2005:

item.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1770 (Hansard, 10 August 2005, page 173) relating to the construction of the Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (IRPC), what is the target sum the contractor, Baulderstone Hornibrook is required to meet for the value of subcontracts awarded to local Christmas Island businesses, what sum has been achieved to date and who are the successful local businesses.
What are the financial incentives and disincentives if the total sum nominated for local Christmas Island business is or alternatively is not met.
Can the Minister confirm that of the 100 people employed on the construction of the IRPC as at 23 June 2005 only one was a local trainee.
What government incentives are in place to promote local training on the project and what has been done by the Department to increase the number of local trainees on the IRPC project.

What discussions have taken place between the Ministerâs department and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs about the use of local Christmas Island businesses and residents for the provision of services needed for the operation and maintenance of the IRPC.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Disclosure of the target sum would disclose Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltdâs (BHPL) pricing strategy to its competitors. BHPL has expended 93% of the target sum to date. In August 2005, the Christmas Island Chamber of Commerce indicated that local involvement in the project has reached local businessâ capacity to respond and the benefits of that involvement were flowing through.
Local subcontractors whose contract values are in excess of $500,000 include:
Crane Hire - Broâs Crane Hire
Concrete Supply - Idoroom Pty Ltd (Trading as Christmas Island Enterprises)
Equipment Hire - Idoroom Pty Ltd (Trading as Christmas Island Enterprises)

If the target sum for local involvement in the project is exceeded, a pro-rata incentive payment will be payable to BHPL. The maximum incentive payment is 2 percent of the target sum if the target sum is doubled.

If the target sum for local involvement in the project is not met, a pro-rata penalty will be payable by BHPL. The maximum disincentive will be a deduction of 2 percent of the target sum if no contracts are awarded to local subcontractors or suppliers.
As at 23 June 2005, BHPL had employed forty-eight local people on site, of which one was a local trainee.

The contractual incentive for local involvement in the project promotes local training. In May 2005 the Department of Finance and Administration (Finance) discussed further training opportunities with BHPL and facilitated discussions between BHPL and the Indian Ocean Group Training scheme. Two additional apprenticeship positions have since been advertised.

I am not aware of any specific meetings between Finance and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) addressing this issue. Financeâs role is to project direct the design and construction of the IRPC. The operation and maintenance of the IRPC is a matter for DIMIA.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, in writing, on 12 September 2005:

item.para: For 2004-2005, what revenue was received for each of the Australian Ports at which container x-ray facilitates operate.
What is the anticipated revenue from each port for 2005-2006.
For 2004-2005, what were the outlays for each port for operating at the port.
What are the anticipated outlays for 2005-2006 for each port for operating the x-ray facilities.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Customs collects revenue through the Import Processing Charge (IPC). The IPC is collected centrally not by region or port. For the 2004-2005 financial year the container examination facility component of the IPC was $19,243,934.

In 2005 the sea cargo component of the IPC will increase to $49.50 per entry with the introduction of the imports module of Customs new Integrated Cargo System (ICS) under Cargo Management Reengineering (CMR). The anticipated revenue from the container examination facility component of the IPC for the 2005-2006 financial year is $30,300,000, calculated using a full year of ICS operation.

The outlays for all the container examination facilities are also measured centrally. All contracts for the facilities are administered through central office and expenditure is not measured by region or port. The outlay for the five container examination facilities for the 2004-2005 financial year was $51.3 million.
The anticipated outlay for the container examination facilities for the 2005-2006 financial year is $65.2 million.

talk.start.para: asked the Minster representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 14Â September 2005:

item.para: Can the Minister confirm media reports that allege a two seat training F/A-18 Hornet jet fighter (number A21-109) has been damaged by inexperienced and unsupervised Fâ111 technicians flown down from RAAF Base Amberley by Boeing to break the strike by members of the Australian Workers Union.

Can the Minister confirm recent media reports that unsupervised and inexperienced Fâ111 technicians employed by Boeing have gouged and cracked a significant structural component of the airframe on one of the RAAFâs eighteen training F/A-18 Hornet jet fighters at the RAAF Base in Williamtown; if so, how long will it take for the aircraft to be operational again.
Can the Minister guarantee that there will be no delays to RAAF pilot training schedules; if not, can the Minister say what delays are likely to occur.

Can the Minister assure the Australian public that the RAAFâs capability to meet national security emergencies has not been compromised by the failure of Boeing to properly maintain one of the RAAFâs F/A-18 Hornet jet fighters.
Does the Commonwealth intend to enforce any legal or contractual rights that it has against Boeing for Boeingâs failure to adequately maintain F/A-18 airframes.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable memberâs question:

item.para: Hornet A21-109 received minor damage while undergoing maintenance by Boeing Australia Limited. The incident is assessed to be consistent with the normal challenges associated with significant structural repairs and deeper aircraft maintenance. Boeing employees and contractors involved were fully trained, competent and working in accordance with appropriate regulations and procedures. Boeing regularly deploys its staff around Australia to meet contractual obligations and has done so as a matter of routine before the industrial action at RAAF Base Williamtown started.

Each aircraft that enters the structural refurbishment and deeper maintenance program comes with varying types and degrees of damage. Hornet A21-109 was found to have above average damage on induction to the repair program. The aircraft will be returned to operational service within the overall program schedule. Precisely when the aircraft is returned to service is an operational matter and will not be disclosed.
There are no delays to the RAAF dual seat F/A 18 pilot training schedules.

The Hornet in question is a dual seat training aircraft and does not form part of the Hornet combat fleet. The readiness of the RAAFâs three F/Aâ18 fighter squadrons, which operate the single seat version, is not compromised by maintenance delays on any one aircraft.
The Commonwealth retains its rights under its contract with Boeing to exercise remedies for non performance. To date, the Commonwealth has not needed to enforce these rights.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Education, Science and Training: Meeting

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, in writing, on 14 September 2005:

item.para: Did he receive a letter dated 16 June 2005 from the TAFE Teachers Association NSW (TAFE TA NSW) Secretary, Ms Linda Simon, seeking a meeting with him in Parliament House on either Monday, 9 August 2005 or Tuesday, 10 August 2005.

Is he aware that Ms Simon and other TAFE TA NSW delegates successfully arranged meetings on these days with NSW Members of Parliament to discuss the funding for TAFE, issues of skills shortages in NSW, the National Training Agenda and the Commonwealth Vocational Education and Training (VET) Funding Agreement.

Is he aware that Ms Simon pursued her request for a meeting by (a) making four follow-up phone calls to his office leaving messages requesting a meeting either in Canberra or in his Electorate Office and (b) briefly visiting his Parliament House office on 10 August 2005 and leaving her contact details.
Is he aware that at the end of August 2005 Ms Simon was contacted by a member of his staff and advised that he was fully committed.
Will he arrange to meet with Ms Linda Simon and TAFE TA NSW delegates at a mutually convenient time; if not, why not.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.
No.

Ms Simon was contacted by my office within three weeks of the receipt of the letter dated 16 June 2005 to regret to the meeting on 9 or 10 August 2005. Ms Simon also made follow up requests for meetings, which were all declined by members of my staff due to my heavily committed programme.
Yes, this was in response to Ms Simon approaching my office in person on 10 August 2005 for a meeting.

My diary is currently overcommitted and I am unable to schedule any time to meet with Ms Simon. As TAFE falls under the portfolio responsibility of my colleague, the Honourable Gary Hardgrave MP, Minister for Vocational and Technical Education, Ms Simon should seek a meeting with Minister Hardgrave.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, in writing, on 15Â September 2005:

item.para: What properties, or lettable floor areas at partially occupied properties, owned by the Commonwealth and in the possession of the department and each agency in the Ministerâs portfolio, are currently not utilised by the department or agency in question, and are not let out.
For how long has each property, or part of a property, identified in part (1) been vacant and why has it been left vacant.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable memberâs question is as follows:

entry.para: Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA)
AFMA has no buildings or floor areas that are both unutilised and not let out.
Note that AFMA owns one small vacant block of residential land on Horn Island in Queensland worth about $50,000.Â
The block has been vacant for over 13 years. It was kept in case AFMA needed a site to build a staff residence. Action is now under way to sell the land.

The Cotton Research and Development Corporation (CRDC) purchased 2 Lloyd Street, Narrabri in October 2001. CRDC has been located in this building since its inception. The building consists of three levels, the top floor being a two bedroom flat which has not been tenanted since the purchase date. CRDC occupies the remaining two floors.
The two bedroom flat has been vacant for four years.

The CRDC has no direct business need for the flat and the commercial costs of upgrading and letting the premises outweigh the benefits of rental return. CRDC also wished to reserve the floor to cater for a potential increase in staff numbers. Following an analysis of its operational needs and the success of the Cotton Catchment Communities CRC bid, CRDC will revisit the potential for letting the space to external parties, following consultation and approval from the Minister.
